message_1: A company has six available employees to work on a project, but they only have the budget to hire three of them. In how many ways can they choose three workers for the project?
message_2:
To determine the number of ways to choose three workers from six employees, we can use the combination formula:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where n is the total number of employees (6) and k is the number of workers to be chosen (3).

C(6, 3) = 6! / (3!(6-3)!)

C(6, 3) = 6! / (3!3!)

C(6, 3) = (6*5*4*3*2*1) / ((3*2*1)*(3*2*1))

C(6, 3) = (720) / (6*6)

C(6, 3) = 720 / 36

C(6, 3) = 20

So there are 20 different ways to choose three workers from the six available employees.
